name: Sasenarine Persaud
bio:
Sasenarine Persaud was born in Guyana and lived in Canada for several years. An essayist, novelist, short story writer, and poet, he is the author of over ten poetry collections, two novels, and a book of short stories. His recent books include Monsoon on the Fingers of God (2018), Love in a Time of Technology (2014), Lantana Strangling Ixora (2011), Unclosed Entrances: Selected Poems (2011), and In a Boston Night (2008). His poetry, essays, and short stories have been published widely and appear in in The Oxford Book of Caribbean Verse and The Oxford Book of Caribbean Short Stories. Persaud’s work braids together Hindu philosophy, myth, and ritual in what he describes as “Yogic Realism.” In The English Language Poetry of South Asians: A Critical Study (2013), Mitali Wong and Syed Hassan called Persaud “a powerful voice for bicultural diaspora South Asians in North America and the Caribbean.”
Persaud’s honors and awards include The KM Hunter Foundation Award, fiction and poetry awards from the Ontario Arts Council and the Canada Council for the Arts, and a fellowship from Boston University. His poetry has been nominated for the Canadian National Magazine Award and the Forward Prize in the UK. He has served as a vice-president and chair of the League of Canadian Poets’ membership committee, as a board director of the Scarborough Arts Council, and on juries for the Toronto Arts Council and the Ontario Arts Council. He presently resides in Tampa, Florida.
